text: Family Member: So they don’t die… Doctor: Correct. Patient: I see oh yeah, yeah, yeah we’re still on that. Doctor: This is a shot that’s - why that shot is important is just because it’s just a one time and then it’s good. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: But the alternative cheaper version of that is a daily shot to keep your cells up. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I know, I’m sorry. Patient: And you would recommend that at least at a minimum? Doctor: Well, you know there’s two ways to approach this. We could wait until you really are in trouble. And in trouble would mean you have a fever, you have no white cells, you better come in to the hospital, you need antibiotics. Patient: Yeah I don’t know (stammering) Doctor: But you’ve already demonstrated that your cells go down. You know you weren’t doing great. I just think we’re asking for trouble. text: Patient: For how long? Doctor: Well that’s what the consent will give you the exact details Patient: Okay, Yeah. Doctor: of how many times a week, but the first few weeks typically are very, what this is called is a Phase I study. So it’s an earlier setting like I said the combination really we don’t have a good handle on what to expect in terms of toxicities, what dose, etc. So one of the side effects that has been noted so far is that the platelets can drop with this medication. So that is something of course the blood counts will be monitored anyway. Besides that kidney function, liver function, all that will also be monitored and checked. You go – undergo EKG monitoring that will be hard test like and echo before you start. So there is a lot of components. One additional component is that you probably will need to do a biopsy again as part of the study. Doctor: So that’s something to think about before you say yes or no. Patient: And does platelets dropping how would that affect me physically? Doctor: Well if it gets really low then it can cause bleeding and things like that - Family Member: Like internal? Doctor: -but the whole idea of this closed monitoring is to not let it get that far. But you know obviously if you notice any bleeding, nose bleeds, gum bleeds, blood in the urine, whatever I need to know right away. Family Member: But how about the bleeding that’s rectal bleeding that he’s having now. Doctor: Yeah, yeah, so has you know we’ll probably have to wait and see, but changes are that should respond to just medical management and will clear up. Family Member: Yeah and you know we had the colonoscopy and the… Doctor: Yeah

text: Patient: Okay. Um, okay well I follow your advice. Family Member: Can I ask a couple questions? Patient: Yes you can. Family Member: Now I can ask? Patient: Now you can talk. text: Patient: This is experimental? Doctor: Correct. Yes. Patient: And uh so I would take the BET1 inhibitor and keep on the Xtandi? Doctor: That’s correct. Patient: And the Lupron? Doctor: So that’s an option. Okay? The other option is do we go now to the medications based on your BRCA mutation should we start you on Lynparza which is one of the medications that are basically given for BRCA mutation patients with prostate cancer. Okay. Family Member: That’s an immunotherapy? Doctor: No that’s a it’s a PARP inhibitor which is known to produce really good responses with this medication, with the BRCA mutant prostate cancer. Okay? Patient: Including BRCA2? Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: That’s the one we had the article about. Doctor: Yeah, so I think you know that is sort of the somewhat well paved route. Okay because it’s known that the response rates are likely to be pretty good. The other way is --

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
